<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1)&nbsp;have filed all reports
required to be filed by Section&nbsp;13 or </I><I>15(d)</I><I> of the Securities Exchange Act of
1934 during the preceding 12&nbsp;months (or for such shorter period that the
registrants were required to file such reports), and (2)&nbsp;have been subject to
such filing requirements for the past 90&nbsp;days. Yes X No&#95;&#95;&#95;


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Indicate by
check mark whether the registrant is an accelerated filer (as defined by Rule
12b-2 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934).</I>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This combined Form 10-Q is separately filed by The Southern Company,
Alabama Power Company, Georgia Power Company, Gulf Power Company, Mississippi
Power Company, Savannah Electric and Power Company and Southern Power Company.

such company on its own behalf. Each company makes no representation as to
information relating to the other companies.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>CAUTIONARY STATEMENT REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING INFORMATION</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q contains forward-looking statements in
addition to historical information. Forward-looking information includes,
among other things, statements concerning the strategic goals for Southern
Company&#146;s wholesale business, estimated construction and other expenditures. In
some cases, forward-looking statements can be identified by terminology such as
&#147;may,&#148; &#147;will,&#148; &#147;could,&#148; &#147;should,&#148; &#147;expects,&#148; &#147;plans,&#148; &#147;anticipates,&#148;
&#147;believes,&#148; &#147;estimates,&#148; &#147;projects,&#148; &#147;predicts,&#148; &#147;potential&#148; or &#147;continue&#148; or
the negative of these terms or other comparable terminology. The registrants
caution that there are various important factors that could cause actual
results to differ materially from those indicated in the forward-looking
statements; accordingly, there can be no assurance that such indicated results
will be realized. These factors include:


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the impact of recent and future federal and state regulatory change, including legislative and regulatory initiatives
regarding deregulation and restructuring of the electric utility industry and also changes in environmental, tax and other
laws and regulations to which Southern Company and its subsidiaries are subject, as well as changes in application of
existing laws and regulations;</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>current and future litigation, regulatory investigations, proceedings or inquiries, including the pending EPA civil actions
against certain Southern Company subsidiaries and current IRS audits;</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<A name='106'></A>
</DIV>




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF RESULTS OF<BR>
OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2004 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Discussion of the results of operations is focused on Southern Company&#146;s
primary business of electricity sales in the Southeast by the retail operating
companies &#150; Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power and
Savannah Electric &#150; and Southern Power. Southern Power is an electric
wholesale generation subsidiary with market-based rate authority. Southern
Company&#146;s other business activities include investments in synthetic fuels and
leveraged lease projects, telecommunications, energy-related services and
natural gas marketing. For additional information on these businesses, see
Item&nbsp;1 &#150; Business &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Retail Operating Companies,&#148;
&#147;Southern Power&#148; and &#147;Other Business&#148; in the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company&#146;s first quarter 2004 earnings were $331&nbsp;million ($0.45
per share) compared with $298&nbsp;million ($0.41 per share) in the first quarter
2003. Earnings in the first quarter 2004 increased due to a number of positive
factors including growth in the number of customers in the Southern Company
service area, successful efforts to control costs and strong results from
Southern Company&#146;s competitive generation business. Southern Company&#146;s
regulated retail business results were positively impacted by customer growth,
increased residential consumption per customer and increased demand by
industrial customers, as well as favorable weather conditions. Earnings from
the competitive generation business continued to favorably affect Southern
Company&#146;s net income due to new generating capacity available for sale in
wholesale markets. This new capacity led to increases in capacity revenues
from new contracts and sales of uncontracted capacity in those wholesale
markets.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Excluding fuel revenues, which generally do not affect net
income, retail base revenues increased by $72&nbsp;million, or 5.2%, in the first
quarter 2004 when compared to the same period in 2003. In the first quarter,
retail kilowatt-hour energy sales increased by 4.5% over the same period a year
ago, primarily due


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">13
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">to customer and demand growth and the improving economy evidenced by increases
in residential and industrial kilowatt-hour energy sales of 5.3% and 5.0%,
respectively, when compared to the same period in 2003.
The number of retail customers increased by 1.7% and weather-adjusted average
consumption by residential customers increased by 4.4% in the first quarter
2004 when compared with the first quarter 2003.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale. </I>During the first quarter 2004, sales for resale
kilowatt-hours decreased by 2.6% when compared to the same period in the prior
year. Sales for resale revenues increased $16.2&nbsp;million, or 4.8%, when
compared to the same period in the prior year. The increase in revenues
reflected new wholesale contracts and increases in fuel revenues. An
additional 2,407 megawatts of generating capacity were added in June and
October&nbsp;2003 by Southern Power. A portion of this new capacity contributed to
the increase in sales for resale revenues for the first quarter 2004 as a
result of capacity revenues from PPAs with neighboring utilities. In addition,
sales from uncontracted capacity provided increased energy revenues. These
increases in sales for resale revenues more than offset the reduction in
revenues resulting from the termination of contracts with subsidiaries of
Dynegy, Inc. in May&nbsp;2003. See Note&nbsp;3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Uncontracted Generating
Capacity&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form&nbsp;10-K for additional
information on these contract terminations.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other revenues. </I>In the first quarter 2004, other revenues increased $17.7
million, or 12.0%. Revenues from Southern Company&#146;s investments in synthetic
fuels increased $18&nbsp;million, primarily as a result of shifting 2004 production
schedules to accelerate production earlier in the year, and retail gas
marketing revenues increased $5&nbsp;million, primarily as a result of colder than
normal weather. These increases were partially offset by a decrease in
revenues from energy-related services of $3&nbsp;million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. During the first quarter 2004, fuel expense was higher due
to an increase in the average unit cost of fuel, as well as increased
generating capacity at Southern Power. Total generation increased 3.1% for
the first quarter 2004, when compared to the same period in the prior year. For
the first quarter 2004, the average unit cost of fuel per net kilowatt-hour
generated increased 3.0% when compared to the same period in the prior year.
Increases in fuel expense at the retail operating companies are generally
offset by fuel revenues and do not affect net income.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power. </I>The decrease in the first quarter 2004 for purchased
power compared with the same period last year is primarily a result of lower
demand for energy. These expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings
since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operations and maintenance expenses. </I>The increase in other
operations and maintenance expenses in the first quarter 2004 is mainly
attributable to increases in administrative and general, transmission and
distribution maintenance and other production expenses. Administrative and
general expenses increased $33.3&nbsp;million, or 15.6%, primarily as a result of
payroll and employee benefits costs as well as an increase of $12.2&nbsp;million in
freight costs related to the production of synthetic fuel. Transmission and
distribution maintenance expenses increased $8.8&nbsp;million as a result of
completing work delayed from 2003. Other production expenses were up $7.0
million, or 5.4%, due to increased expenses primarily resulting from the
operation of Southern Power&#146;s new generating facilities.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes. </I>The first quarter 2004 increase in taxes
other than income taxes over the comparable period last year is primarily a
result of increases in payroll taxes and property taxes on new facilities.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">14
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Equity in losses of unconsolidated subsidiaries. </I>Losses from
unconsolidated subsidiaries increased in the first quarter 2004 when compared
to the corresponding period in 2003. These losses relate primarily to Southern
Company&#146;s investments in entities that produce synthetic fuel. Changes between
periods are a result of fluctuations in production levels and are generally
offset by income tax credits generated by such entities.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized. </I>The increase in interest
expense, net of amounts capitalized in the first quarter 2004 when compared to
the same period in 2003 is mainly attributable to an increase in the amount of
senior notes outstanding and lower amounts of interest capitalized as projects
have reached completion, partially offset by refinancing long-term debt with
lower interest-rate debt. See Financial Condition and Liquidity &#150; &#147;Financing
Activities&#148; herein for additional information. Capitalized interest decreased
by $6.1&nbsp;million, or 33.8%, during the first quarter 2004 when compared to the
corresponding period in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Distributions on mandatorily redeemable preferred securities. </I>The
decrease in distributions on mandatorily redeemable preferred securities is a
result of refinancing a portion of those securities with proceeds from
long-term senior notes issuances or equity funds. See Accounting Policies &#150;
&#147;New Accounting Standards&#148; herein for related information regarding Southern
Company&#146;s adoption of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable
Interest Entities.&#148;


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors. These factors include the retail operating companies&#146; ability to
maintain a stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth while
containing costs and to recover costs related to growing demand and
increasingly stricter environmental standards. Another major factor is
the profitability of the competitive market-based wholesale generating business
and federal regulatory policy, which may impact Southern Company&#146;s level of
participation in this market. Future earnings for the electricity business in
the near term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which is
subject to a number of factors, including weather, competition, new energy
contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by
customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand and the
rate of economic growth in the service area. For additional information
relating to these issues, see Item&nbsp;1 &#151; Business &#151; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk
Factors&#148; and Item&nbsp;7 &#150; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential&#148; of Southern Company in the<BR>
Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For
additional information, including information on certain environmental
litigation, see Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Southern Company and Note 3 to
the financial statements of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K under
&#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; and &#147;Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation.&#148; As
of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were increased
prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the extent
alleged violations under either the New Source Review Litigation or Plant
Wansley Environmental Litigation are deemed to be continuing, this increased
civil penalty amount could apply to such violations found to continue after
that date. On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to
review the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">15
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Source Review action against the TVA. The cases against Alabama Power, Georgia
Power and Savannah Electric have been effectively stayed pending final
resolution of the TVA appeal. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for review,
the Court of Appeals&#146; decision is now final. An adverse outcome in any one of
these cases could require substantial capital expenditures that cannot be
determined at this time and could possibly require payment of substantial
penalties. This could affect future results of operations, cash flows, and
possibly financial condition if such costs are not recovered through regulated
rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;12, 2004, the EPA redesignated the Birmingham, Alabama area from
nonattainment to attainment under the one-hour ozone national ambient air
quality standard. On April&nbsp;30, 2004, the EPA published its eight-hour ozone
nonattainment designations and a portion of the rules implementing the new
eight-hour standard. Areas within the Southern Company&#146;s service area that
have been designated as nonattainment under the eight-hour ozone standard
include Birmingham, Macon (Georgia), and a 20-county area within metropolitan
Atlanta. Under the implementation provisions of the new rule, the EPA
announced that the one-hour ozone standard will be revoked on June&nbsp;15, 2005. Areas
classified as &#147;severe&#148; nonattainment areas under the one-hour standard will not
be required to impose emissions fees as a result of nonattainment. Georgia
Power, therefore, will no longer be subject to imposition of emissions fees if
the Atlanta area does not come into attainment with the one-hour standard. The
impact of the eight-hour designations and the new standards will depend on the
development and implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore
cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;21, 2004, the EPA published the final regional nitrogen oxide
reduction rules applicable to Georgia. These rules specify that Georgia must
submit a revised state implementation plan by April&nbsp;2005, and affected sources
must comply with the reduction requirements by May&nbsp;1, 2007. The impact of
these regulations will depend on the development and approval of Georgia&#146;s
state implementation plan and cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, on April&nbsp;15, 2004, the EPA announced proposed amendments to
its Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology
(BART)&nbsp;guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend
on the development and implementation of the final rules and implementation by
the states, and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#150; FERC
Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;FERC Matters&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued an order that
abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis for measuring
generation market power. The FERC also initiated a new rulemaking proceeding
that, among other things, will adopt a final methodology for assessing
generation market power. See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; herein for additional information. Southern Company
anticipates filing a request for rehearing of the order. The final outcome of
this matter cannot be determined at this time.

</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plant McIntosh Units 10 and 11 are currently under construction by
Southern Power and are scheduled to be completed in June&nbsp;2005. See Note 3 to
Southern Company&#146;s financial statements under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K and Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for
information regarding the FERC approval process for Southern Power&#146;s PPAs with
Georgia Power and Savannah Electric for Plant McIntosh Units 10 and 11.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential &#151; FERC Matters&#148; of Southern Company in the Form 10-K for information
on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the FERC&#146;s notice of proposed
rulemaking regarding open access transmission service and standard electricity
market design.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Mirant Related Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant
Related Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 and Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; Other Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and Note (B)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements herein under &#147;Mirant Related Matters&#148;. In
July&nbsp;2003, Mirant filed for voluntary reorganization under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the
Federal Bankruptcy Code. Southern Company has various contingent liabilities
associated with Mirant, including guarantees of contractual commitments,
litigation and joint and several liabilities in connection with the
consolidated federal income tax return. The ultimate outcome of such
contingent liabilities cannot now be determined.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Income Tax Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Item&nbsp;7&#151;
Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential
&#151; Income Tax Matters&#148; of Southern Company and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Income Tax Issues&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for information regarding IRS and other challenges to Southern Company&#146;s
transactions related to synthetic fuel tax credits and international leveraged
leases. See Note (B) to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for
information on potential additional challenges related to the international
leveraged leases. The ultimate outcome of these matters cannot now be
determined.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In January&nbsp;2002, Georgia Power began operating under a three-year retail rate
order. Under the terms of the order, earnings are evaluated annually against a
retail return on common equity range of 10&nbsp;percent to 12.95&nbsp;percent.
Two-thirds of any earnings above the 12.95&nbsp;percent return will be applied to
rate refunds, with the remaining one-third retained by Georgia Power. Georgia
Power is required to file a general rate case on July&nbsp;1, 2004, in response to
which the Georgia PSC would be expected to determine whether the rate order
should be continued, modified, or discontinued. See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#150; Other Matters&#148; and Note
3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Georgia Power Retail
Rate Orders&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Note 3 to Southern Company&#146;s financial statements under &#147;Mississippi
Power Regulatory Filing&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (I)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for information on Mississippi Power&#146;s
request to include 266 megawatts of Plant Daniel Units 3 and 4 generating
capacity in jurisdictional cost of service. The final outcome of this matter
cannot now be determined.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">17
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Power is completing limited construction activities on Plant
Franklin Unit 3 to preserve the long-term viability of the project
but has deferred final completion until the 2008-2011 period. See Note 3 to
Southern Company&#146;s financial statements under &#147;Uncontracted Generating
Capacity&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. The final
outcome of these matters cannot now be determined.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151;
Other Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on nuclear security
measures. Implementation plans for the measures ordered by the NRC to be in
effect by October&nbsp;29, 2004 have been finalized based on current interpretations
of the requirements. Alabama Power and Georgia Power &#151; based on its ownership
interest &#150; currently estimate their respective expenditures related to these
security measures to total $9.6&nbsp;million and $9.3&nbsp;million, of which $9.3&nbsp;million
and $1.3&nbsp;million will be capitalized. These estimates are subject to change in
the event additional NRC guidance is provided.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in
the ordinary course of business. In addition, Southern Company&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The
ultimate outcome of such litigation against Southern Company and its
subsidiaries cannot be predicted at this time; however, management does not
anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings
would have a material adverse effect on Southern Company&#146;s financial
statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company prepares its financial statements in accordance with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant
accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of
Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on
Southern Company&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different
assumptions and measurements could produce estimates that are significantly
different from those recorded in the financial statements. See Item&nbsp;7 -
Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Accounting
Policies &#151; Application of Critical Accounting
Policies and Estimates&#148; of Southern Company in the Form 10-K for a complete
discussion of Southern Company&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates
related to Electric Utility
Regulation, Contingent Obligations, and Plant Daniel Capacity. Also see Note
(I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information
related to Mississippi Power&#146;s request to include the Plant Daniel capacity in
jurisdictional cost of service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Southern Company prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation
No.&nbsp;46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the
primary beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the
related assets and liabilities. The adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no
impact on Southern Company&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption,
Southern Company and the retail operating companies


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">18
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred
securities since Southern Company and the retail operating companies do not
meet the definition of primary beneficiary established by Interpretation No.
46R. In addition, Southern Company consolidated its 85% limited partnership
investment in an energy/telecom venture capital fund that was previously
accounted for under the equity method. See Note (E)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information related to the adoption of
Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Southern Company&#146;s financial condition during the first three
months of 2004 included $513&nbsp;million used for gross property additions to
utility plant. The funds for these additions and other capital requirements
were primarily obtained from operating activities and net proceeds from
security issuances of approximately $533&nbsp;million. See Southern Company&#146;s
Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows and &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein for further details.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151;
&#147;Capital Requirements and
Contractual Obligations&#148; of Southern Company in the Form 10-K for a description
of Southern Company&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, and
other funding requirements associated with scheduled maturities of long-term
debt, as well as the related interest, preferred stock dividends, leases, trust
funding requirements and other purchase commitments. Approximately $1.1
billion will be required by March&nbsp;31, 2005 for redemptions and maturities of
long-term debt.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company intends to meet its future capital needs through internal cash
flow and external security issuances. The amounts and timing of additional
equity capital to be raised will be contingent on Southern Company&#146;s investment
opportunities. The retail operating companies and Southern Power plan to
obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those used in the past, which were primarily from operating cash
flows, security issuances and term loan and short-term borrowings. However,
the amount, type and timing of any financings, if needed, will depend upon
market conditions and regulatory approval. See Item&nbsp;1 &#151; Business &#151; &#147;Financing
Programs&#148; and Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Financial
Condition And Liquidity &#150; Sources of Capital&#148; of Southern Company in the Form
10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company&#146;s current liabilities exceed current assets because of
the continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs, as
well as scheduled maturities of long-term debt. To meet short-term cash needs
and contingencies, the Southern Company system had at March&nbsp;31, 2004
approximately $325&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and approximately $3.5
billion of unused credit arrangements with banks, of which $2.8&nbsp;billion expire
in 2004, $10&nbsp;million expire in 2005 and $660&nbsp;million expire in 2006 and beyond.
Of the
facilities maturing in 2004 and 2005, $2.2&nbsp;billion contain provisions allowing
two-year term loans executable at the expiration date and $225&nbsp;million contain
provisions allowing one-year term loans executable at the expiration date.
These unused credit arrangements also provide liquidity support to variable
rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper programs. Southern Company
expects to  renew its credit facilities, as


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">19
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">needed, prior to expiration. The retail operating companies may also meet
short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue
and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and
for the benefit of each of the retail operating companies. At March&nbsp;31, 2004,
the Southern Company system had outstanding extendible commercial notes of $4
million and outstanding commercial paper of $671&nbsp;million. Management believes
that the need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial
paper programs and lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Financial Condition and
Liquidity &#150; Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements&#148; of Southern Company and
Note 7 to the financial statements of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; for information related to Mississippi Power&#146;s
lease of a combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company and its subsidiaries do not have any credit agreements that
would require material changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result
of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts that could require
collateral &#151; but not accelerated payment &#151; in the event of a credit rating
change to below investment grade. These contracts are primarily for physical
electricity purchases and sales, fixed-price physical gas purchases and
agreements covering interest rate swaps. At March&nbsp;31, 2004, the maximum
potential collateral requirements were approximately $426&nbsp;million. Generally,
collateral may be provided for by a Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit
or cash.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Southern Company&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have
not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting period.
In addition, Southern Company is not aware of any facts or circumstances that
would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, the retail operating companies have
limited exposure to market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices
and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in
electricity prices, the retail operating companies and Southern Power enter
into fixed price contracts for the purchase and sale of electricity through the
wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser extent, similar contracts for gas
purchases. Also, the retail operating companies have each implemented
fuel-hedging programs at the instruction of their respective PSCs. The fair
value of derivative energy contracts at March&nbsp;31, 2004 was as follows:

Form 10-K and Note (G)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">During the first quarter of 2004, Southern Company subsidiaries issued $590
million of senior notes, $208&nbsp;million of other long-term debt, $100&nbsp;million of preferred stock and $49&nbsp;million of common stock through employee
and directors stock plans. The issuances were primarily used to refund senior
notes and other long-term debt. The remainder was used to repay short-term
debt and fund ongoing construction programs. See Southern Company&#146;s Condensed
Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details on financing
activities during the first three months of 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $100&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;S 4.00%
Senior Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2011 and $100&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;T 5.75% Senior
Public Income Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2044. The proceeds from these sales were
used in March&nbsp;2004 to redeem all of its outstanding Series&nbsp;H 6.70% Senior
Insured Quarterly Notes due March&nbsp;1, 2011 and Series&nbsp;D 6 5/8% Senior Notes due
March&nbsp;31, 2039.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further in January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power Capital Trust VII, a statutory
trust, sold $200&nbsp;million of its 5 7/8% Trust Preferred Securities,
which are guaranteed by Georgia Power. The net proceeds from this issuance
were used to redeem 6.85% Trust Preferred Securities of Georgia Power Capital
Trust IV. In connection with this transaction, Georgia Power issued $206
million of its junior subordinated debentures to Georgia Power Capital Trust
VII.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued 4,000,000 shares ($100&nbsp;million
aggregate stated capital) of 5.30% Class&nbsp;A Preferred Stock, Cumulative, Par
Value $1 Per Share (Stated Capital $25 Per Share) and $200&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;Z
5.125% Senior Notes due February&nbsp;15, 2019. The proceeds from these sales were
used to repay a portion of Alabama Power&#146;s outstanding short-term indebtedness
and for other general corporate purposes, including Alabama Power&#146;s continuous
construction program.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">21
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also in February&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $150&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;U
Floating Rate Senior Notes due February&nbsp;17, 2009. The proceeds of this sale
were used for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued $40&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;F Floating
Rate Senior Notes due March&nbsp;9, 2009. The proceeds from this sale, along with
other monies of Mississippi Power were used to repay $80&nbsp;million aggregate
principal amount of Mississippi Power&#146;s Series&nbsp;D Floating Rate Senior Notes due
March&nbsp;12, 2004.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, in April&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued $150&nbsp;million of Series
AA 5.625% Senior Notes due April&nbsp;15, 2034. The proceeds from the sale will be
used together with other funds to redeem, in May&nbsp;2004, $200&nbsp;million in
aggregate principal amount of Alabama Power&#146;s Series&nbsp;J 6.75% Senior Notes due
June&nbsp;30, 2039.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also in April&nbsp;2004, Gulf Power issued $35&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;J 5.875%
Senior Notes due April&nbsp;1, 2044. The proceeds from this issue were used for
general corporate purposes, including Gulf Power&#146;s continuous construction
program.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further, in April&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued 1,200,000 Depositary
Shares ($30&nbsp;million aggregate stated capital) each representing one-fourth of a
share of 5.25% Series&nbsp;Preferred Stock cumulative, par value $100 per share.
The proceeds from this sale were primarily used to redeem various issues of
preferred stock and the remainder was used for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries plan to continue, to the extent
possible, a program to retire higher-cost debt and replace these securities
with lower-cost capital.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The market price of Southern Company&#146;s common stock at March&nbsp;31, 2004 was
$30.50 per share and the book value was $13.26 per share, representing a
market-to-book ratio of 230%, compared to $30.25, $13.13 and 230%,
respectively, at the end of 2003. The dividend for the first quarter 2004 was
$0.35 per share compared to $0.3425 per share in the first quarter 2003.

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<DIV align="left">
<A name='139'></A>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Item&nbsp;4. Controls and Procedures.</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;Evaluation of disclosure controls and procedures.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">As of the end of the period covered by this quarterly report, Southern Company,
the retail operating companies and Southern Power conducted separate
evaluations under the supervision and with the participation of each company&#146;s
management, including the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial
Officer, of the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures (as
defined in Sections&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) of the Securities Exchange Act of
1934). Based upon those evaluations, the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief
Financial Officer, in each case, concluded that the disclosure controls and
procedures are effective in alerting them in a timely manner to material
information relating to each company (including its consolidated subsidiaries)
required to be included in periodic filings with the SEC.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;Changes in internal controls.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">There have been no changes in Southern Company&#146;s, the retail operating
companies&#146; or Southern Power&#146;s internal controls over financial reporting (as
such term is defined in Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities
Exchange Act of 1934) during the first quarter of 2004 that have materially
affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect, Southern Company&#146;s, the
retail operating companies&#146; or Southern Power&#146;s internal controls over
financial reporting.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">23
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2004 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the first
quarter 2004 was $90.7&nbsp;million compared to $91.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding
period of 2003. Earnings in the first quarter of 2004 decreased by $1.1
million, or 1.2%, primarily due to higher operation and maintenance expenses,
depreciation expense and taxes other than income taxes. These increases were
partially offset by an increase in retail base-rate revenues and a decrease in
interest expense.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<DIV align="center">

</DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales</I>. Excluding energy cost recovery revenues and revenues
associated with PPAs certificated by the Alabama PSC, which generally do not
affect net income, retail sales revenues increased by $21.6&nbsp;million, or 4.3%,
for the first quarter 2004 when compared to the corresponding period in 2003.
See Note 3 to Alabama Power&#146;s financial statements under &#147;Retail Rate
Adjustment Procedures&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
Kilowatt-hour energy sales to residential, commercial, and industrial customers
increased 4.4%, 2.6%, and 8.9%, respectively, for the first quarter 2004 when
compared to the corresponding period of 2003 primarily due to favorable weather
conditions and improved industrial sales mainly in the primary metal and
automotive sectors.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; non-affiliates. </I>During the first quarter 2004, the
revenues associated with sales for resale to non-affiliates decreased due to a
5.7% reduction in kilowatt-hour sales of energy while market based prices
remained flat when compared to the first quarter of 2003. Kilowatt-hour sales
of energy will vary depending on demand, market based prices and the
availability of Southern Company system generation. These transactions did not
have a significant impact on earnings since the energy is usually sold at
variable cost.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">30
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates and Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Sales for
resale to affiliates increased in the first quarter 2004 when compared to the
corresponding period in 2003 due to a $1.0&nbsp;million increase in capacity
payments received in accordance with the affiliated company interchange
agreement as a result of Alabama Power&#146;s increased share of the total
interchange capacity. Purchases of energy will vary depending on demand and
the availability and cost of generating resources at each company. Purchased
power from affiliates increased in the first quarter 2004 principally due to a
PPA between Alabama Power and Southern Power that began in June&nbsp;2003. The
capacity component of these transactions was $9.4&nbsp;million in the first quarter
2004. Excluding the capacity revenue received under the interchange agreement,
these transactions did not have a significant impact on earnings since the
related energy is sold at marginal cost, and energy purchases are generally
offset by energy revenues through Alabama Power&#146;s energy cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>Fuel expense was higher in the first quarter 2004 when
compared to the corresponding period in 2003 mainly due to a 26.7% increase in
natural gas prices and a 36.3% increase in generation from natural gas-fired
generating facilities. The increase in generation from gas-fired facilities in
the first quarter 2004 when compared to the first quarter 2003 is mainly due to
a 27.1% decrease in generation from Alabama Power&#146;s hydroelectric facilities.
Since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues, these expenses
do not have a significant impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operation expense. </I>The increase in other operation expense in the
first quarter 2004 is a result of an $11.1&nbsp;million increase in administrative
and general expenses. This increase primarily relates to a $4.9&nbsp;million
increase in employee payroll and benefits, and legal expenses, a $1.9&nbsp;million
increase in property insurance, a $1.9&nbsp;million increase in accrued expense for
liability insurance, litigation and workers compensation and a $1.8&nbsp;million
increase in pension expense.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The increase in maintenance expense for the first
quarter 2004 when compared to the same period in 2003 is attributed to a $3.3
million increase in distribution expense and a $1.7&nbsp;million increase in
transmission expense. These increases are mainly related to scheduled work
performed on overhead lines.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization expense. </I>The increase in depreciation and
amortization expense during the first quarter 2004 is attributed to an increase
in utility plant-in-service when compared to the same period in 2003. See Note
7 to Alabama Power&#146;s financial statements under &#147;Construction Program&#148; in Item
8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Taxes other than income taxes. </I>The first quarter 2004 increase in taxes
other than income taxes is due to a $2.3&nbsp;million increase in payroll taxes and
a $1.3&nbsp;million increase in property taxes when compared to the corresponding
period in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized. </I>The decrease in interest
expense, net of amounts capitalized during the first quarter 2004 when compared
to the same period in 2003 is the result of refinancing higher cost debt. For
additional information, see &#147;Financial Condition and Liquidity &#151; Financing
Activities&#148; herein.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">31
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Alabama Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly strict environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors. These
factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring
utilities, energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of
electricity, the price elasticity of demand and the rate of economic growth in
Alabama Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating to these
issues, see Item&nbsp;1 &#151; Business &#150; The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; and Item&nbsp;7
&#150; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Alabama
Power in the Form 10-K.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For
additional information about these issues, including the EPA litigation, see
Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential -
Environmental Matters&#148; and Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama Power
under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15,
2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were increased prospectively to a
maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the extent alleged violations
under the New Source Review Litigation are deemed to be continuing, this
increased civil penalty amount could apply to such violations found to continue
after that date. On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition
to review the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New
Source Review action against the TVA. The case against Alabama Power has been
effectively stayed pending final resolution of the TVA appeal. With the denial
of the EPA&#146;s petition for review, the Court of Appeals&#146; decision is now final. An
adverse outcome in this case could require substantial capital expenditures
that cannot be determined at this time and could possibly require payment of
substantial penalties. This could affect future results of operations, cash
flows, and possibly financial condition if such costs are not recovered through
regulated rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;12, 2004, the EPA redesignated the Birmingham, Alabama area from
nonattainment to attainment under the one-hour ozone national ambient air
quality standard. On April&nbsp;30, 2004, the EPA published its eight-hour ozone
nonattainment designations and a portion of the rules implementing the new
eight-hour standard. Within Alabama Power&#146;s service area, Birmingham has been
designated as nonattainment under the eight-hour ozone standard. Under the
implementation provisions of the new rule, the EPA announced that the one-hour
ozone standard will be revoked on June&nbsp;15, 2005. The impact of the eight-hour designations
and the new standards will depend on the development and implementation of
applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be determined at this time.
Additionally, on April&nbsp;15, 2004, the EPA announced proposed amendments to its
Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology (BART)
guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend on the
development and implementation of the final rules and implementation by the
states, and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#150; FERC
Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Alabama Power under &#147;FERC


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">32
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued an
order that abandoned the SMA test and adopted a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power. The FERC also initiated a new rulemaking
proceeding that, among other things, will adopt a final methodology for
assessing generation market
power. See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;FERC Matters&#148;
herein for additional information. Southern Company is filing a
request for rehearing of the FERC&#146;s order. The final outcome of this matter
cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential &#150; FERC Matters&#148; of Alabama Power in the Form 10-K for information on
the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking
regarding open access transmission service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Item&nbsp;7 &#151;
Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; Other
Matters&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on nuclear security
measures. Implementation plans for the measures ordered by the NRC to be in
effect by October&nbsp;29, 2004 have been finalized based on current interpretations
of the requirements. Alabama Power currently estimates its expenditures related to
these security measures to total $9.6&nbsp;million of which $9.3&nbsp;million will be
capitalized. These estimates are subject to change in the event additional NRC
guidance is provided.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in
the ordinary course of business. In addition, Alabama Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The
ultimate outcome of such litigation against Alabama Power cannot be predicted
at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if
any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect
on Alabama Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Alabama Power
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have a material impact on Alabama Power&#146;s results
of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements
could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in
the financial statements. See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis -
&#147;Accounting Policies &#151; Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Alabama Power in
the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Alabama Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation and Contingent
Obligations.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">33
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Alabama Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation No.
46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related assets and
liabilities. The adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on Alabama
Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption, Alabama Power
deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred
securities since Alabama Power does not meet the definition of primary
beneficiary established by Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (E)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information related to the
adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.


<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Alabama Power&#146;s financial condition during the first three
months of 2004 included the addition of approximately $204&nbsp;million to utility
plant. The funds for these additions and other capital requirements were
derived primarily from operating activities and net proceeds from security
issuances of $319&nbsp;million. See Alabama Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash
Flows herein for further details.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis &#151; Financial Condition And Liquidity &#151;  &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Alabama Power in of the Form 10-K
for a description of Alabama Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction
program, lease obligations, purchase commitments and trust funding
requirements. Approximately $725&nbsp;million will be required by March&nbsp;31, 2005
for redemptions and maturities of long-term debt.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described below,
Alabama Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other
purposes from sources similar to those used in the past. The amount, type and
timing of any financings &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon maintenance of
adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions and other
factors. See Item&nbsp;1 &#151; Business &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in the Form
10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power&#146;s current liabilities exceed current assets primarily
because of scheduled maturities of long-term debt. To meet short-term cash
needs and contingencies, at March&nbsp;31, 2004 Alabama Power had $166&nbsp;million of
cash and cash equivalents, unused committed lines of credit of approximately
$865&nbsp;million (including $504&nbsp;million of such lines which are dedicated to
funding purchase obligations relating to variable rate pollution control bonds)
and an extendible commercial note program. These lines of credit will
expire at various times during 2004. Alabama Power expects to renew
its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. Alabama Power may also
meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to
issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request
and for the benefit of Alabama Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries.
Alabama Power has regulatory authority for up to $1&nbsp;billion of short-term
borrowings. At March&nbsp;31, 2004, Alabama Power had no commercial paper or notes
payable outstanding. Management believes that the need for working capital can
be adequately met by issuing commercial paper or utilizing lines of credit
without maintaining large cash balances.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">34
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power does not have any credit agreements that would require material
changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating
downgrade. There are contracts that could require collateral &#150; but not
accelerated payment &#150; in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales, fixed price physical gas purchases and agreements covering
interest rate swaps. At March&nbsp;31, 2004, the maximum potential collateral
requirements were approximately $27&nbsp;million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Alabama Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have
not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting period.
In addition, Alabama Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances that
would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Alabama Power has limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Alabama Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase and
sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser
extent, similar contracts for gas purchases. Alabama Power has also
implemented a retail fuel hedging program at the instruction of the Alabama
PSC. The fair value of derivative energy contracts at March&nbsp;31, 2004 was as
follows:

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and
Analysis &#151; &#147;Financial Condition And Liquidity &#151; Market Price Risk&#148; of Alabama
Power in the Form 10-K and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Alabama
Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (G)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In February&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued 500,000 shares of common stock to
Southern Company at $40.00 a share ($20&nbsp;million aggregate purchase price). The
proceeds from the sale were used by Alabama Power for general corporate
purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also in February&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued 4,000,000 shares ($100&nbsp;million
aggregate stated capital) of 5.30% Class&nbsp;A Preferred Stock, Cumulative, Par
Value $1 per share (Stated Capital $25 Per Share) and $200&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;Z
5.125% Senior Notes due February&nbsp;15, 2019. The proceeds from the sale were
used to repay a portion of Alabama Power&#146;s outstanding short-term indebtedness
and for other general corporate purposes, including Alabama Power&#146;s continuous
construction program.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2004, Alabama Power issued $150&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;AA 5.625%
Senior Notes due April&nbsp;15, 2034. The proceeds from the sale will be used
together with other funds to redeem in May&nbsp;2004 $200&nbsp;million in aggregate
principal amount of the Series&nbsp;J 6.75% Senior Notes due June&nbsp;30, 2039.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to
retire higher-cost debt and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital
if market conditions permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">36
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2004 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the
first quarter 2004 was $143.9&nbsp;million compared to $133.3&nbsp;million for the
corresponding period in 2003. Earnings in the first quarter 2004 increased by
$10.6&nbsp;million, or 7.9%, primarily due to higher retail revenues that were
partially offset by higher non-fuel operating expenses when compared to the
same period in 2003.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:
