<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">N/M Not meaningful</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Excluding fuel revenues, which generally do not affect net
income, retail sales revenue increased by $31.8&nbsp;million, or 4.7%, in the first
quarter 2004 compared to the corresponding period in 2003. In the first
quarter 2004, kilowatt-hour energy sales to residential, commercial and
industrial customers increased by 5.3%, 3.9% and 2.1%, respectively, when
compared to the same period in 2003. These increases in the retail sectors
during the first quarter 2004 are mainly due to customer growth of 2% and an
improving economy.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; non-affiliates</I>. The decrease in revenues from sales
for resale to non-affiliates in the first quarter 2004 is mainly attributed to
lower demand for energy by these customers when compared to the same period in
2003. These transactions did not have a significant impact on earnings since
the energy is usually sold at variable cost.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">43
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates</I>. Revenues from sales for resale to
affiliates increased in the first quarter 2004 when compared to the same period
in 2003 despite lower demand for energy due to higher fuel costs associated
with generating electricity. These transactions did not have a significant
impact on earnings since this energy is generally sold at marginal cost.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other revenues. </I>The increase in other revenues during the first quarter
2004 when compared to the corresponding period of 2003 is primarily attributed
to a $1.4&nbsp;million increase in outdoor lighting revenues and a $0.7&nbsp;million
increase in electric property rental revenues.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense</I>. During the first quarter 2004, fuel expenses increased as a
result of a 15.1% increase in the unit cost of fuel when compared to the
corresponding period in 2003 and an increase of 2.5% in generation due to
increased retail sales. These expenses do not have a significant impact on
earnings since fuel expenses are generally offset by fuel revenues through
Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; non-affiliates. </I>The first quarter 2004 decrease in
purchased power from non-affiliates is primarily due to fluctuations in
off-system energy purchases used to meet off-system sales commitments. These
expenses do not have a significant impact on earnings since energy expenses are
generally offset by energy revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery
clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Purchased power from affiliates
increased in the first quarter 2004 when compared to the first quarter 2003 due
to a PPA between Georgia Power and Southern Power that began in June&nbsp;2003. The
capacity component of these transactions totaled $10.7&nbsp;million in the first
quarter 2004. The energy component of power purchased from affiliated
companies within the Southern Company system will vary depending on demand and
the availability and cost of generating resources at each company and will have
no significant impact on earnings since energy expenses are generally offset by
energy revenues through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operation expense. </I>Other operation expense in the first quarter
2004 was higher when compared to the same period in 2003 due to increased
administrative and general expenses of $10.8&nbsp;million related to employee
payroll and benefits and $3.2&nbsp;million in workers compensation benefits.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization. </I>In the first quarter 2004, depreciation
and amortization expense was lower compared to the first quarter of 2003. This
decrease was caused primarily by lower regulatory charges needed to levelize
purchased power capacity costs under the terms of the retail rate order
effective January&nbsp;1, 2002. This decrease was offset by an increase in
affiliated purchased power costs discussed above. See Note 1 to the financial
statements under &#147;Depreciation and Amortization&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest income. </I>During the first quarter 2004, interest income increased
when compared to the corresponding period in 2003 due mainly to interest
received from the State of Georgia for a favorable sales and use tax
settlement.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other income (expense), net. </I>The change in this item in the first quarter 2004
when compared to the first quarter 2003 reflects decreased income from a new
electricity pricing program.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">44
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Georgia Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price
elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic growth in the service area. For
additional information relating to these issues, see Item&nbsp;1 &#151; Business &#150; The
SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; and Item&nbsp;7 &#150; Management&#146;s Discussion and
Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Georgia Power in the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot be recovered. For
additional information, including information on certain environmental
litigation, see Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; of Georgia Power and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K under &#147;New
Source Review Actions&#148; and &#147;Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation.&#148; As of
March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were increased
prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the extent
alleged violations under either the New Source Review litigation or Plant
Wansley Environmental litigation are deemed to be continuing, this increased
civil penalty amount could apply to such violations found to continue after
that date. On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to
review the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New
Source Review action against the TVA. The case
against Georgia Power has been effectively stayed pending final resolution of
the TVA appeal. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for review, the Court of
Appeals&#146; decision is now final. An adverse outcome in either of these cases
could require substantial capital expenditures that cannot be determined at
this time and could possibly require payment of substantial
penalties. This could affect future results of operations, cash flows
and possibly financial condition if such costs are not recovered
through regulated rates.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;30, 2004, the EPA published its eight-hour ozone nonattainment
designations and a portion of the rules implementing the new eight-hour
standard. Areas within Georgia Power&#146;s service area that have been designated
as nonattainment under the eight-hour ozone standard include Macon and a
20-county area within metropolitan Atlanta. Under the implementation
provisions of the new rule, the EPA announced that the one-hour ozone standard
will be revoked on June&nbsp;15, 2005. Areas classified as &#147;severe&#148; nonattainment areas
under the one-hour standard will not be required to impose emissions fees as a
result of nonattainment. Georgia Power, therefore, will no longer be subject
to imposition of emissions fees if the Atlanta area does not come into
attainment with the one-hour standard. The impact of the eight-hour
designations and the new standards will depend on the development and
implementation of applicable state regulations and therefore cannot be
determined at this time.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;21, 2004, the EPA published the final regional nitrogen oxide
reduction rules applicable to the State of Georgia. These rules specify that
Georgia must submit a revised state implementation plan by April&nbsp;2005, and
affected sources must comply with the reduction requirements by May&nbsp;1, 2007.
The impact of these regulations will depend on the development and approval of
Georgia&#146;s state implementation plan and cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">45
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, on April&nbsp;15, 2004, the EPA announced proposed amendments to
its Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology
(BART)&nbsp;guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend
on the development and implementation of the final rules and implementation by
the states, and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Management&#146;s Discussion And Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#150; FERC
Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Georgia Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.
On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued an order that abandoned the SMA test and
adopted a new interim analysis for measuring generation market power. The FERC
also initiated a new rulemaking proceeding that, among other things, will adopt
a final methodology for assessing generation market
power. See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;FERC Matters&#148;
herein for additional information. Southern Company is filing a
request for rehearing the FERC&#146;s
order. The final outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;FERC
Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for information regarding the FERC approval process for
Southern Power&#146;s PPAs with Georgia Power and Savannah Electric for Plant
McIntosh Units 10 and 11.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential &#151; FERC Matters&#148; and Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia
Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on the
FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the FERC&#146;s notice of proposed rulemaking
regarding open access transmission service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In January&nbsp;2002, Georgia Power began operating under a three-year retail rate
order. Under the terms of the order, earnings will be evaluated annually
against a retail return on common equity range of 10&nbsp;percent to 12.95&nbsp;percent.
Two-thirds of any earnings above the 12.95&nbsp;percent return will be applied to
rate refunds, with the remaining one-third retained by Georgia Power. Retail
rates were decreased by $118&nbsp;million effective January&nbsp;1, 2002. Purchases
under PPAs are required by the order to be reflected in rates evenly over the
three year period ending December&nbsp;31, 2004. Georgia Power is required to file
a general rate case on July&nbsp;1, 2004, in response to which the Georgia PSC would
be expected to determine whether the rate order should be continued, modified,
or discontinued. See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#150; Other Matters&#148; and Note 3 to the financial statements of
Georgia Power under &#147;Retail Rate Orders&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In August&nbsp;2003, the Georgia PSC issued an order allowing Georgia Power to
increase customer fuel rates to recover existing under-recovered deferred fuel
costs over the period October&nbsp;1, 2003 through March&nbsp;31, 2005. See Note 3 to
the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for additional information.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">46
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151;
Other Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on nuclear security
measures. Implementation plans for the measures ordered by the NRC to be in
effect by October&nbsp;29, 2004 have been finalized based on current interpretations
of the requirements. Georgia Power, based on its ownership interest,
currently estimates
its expenditures related to these security measures will total
$9.3&nbsp;million, of
which $1.3&nbsp;million will be capitalized. These estimates are subject to change
in the event additional NRC guidance is provided.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2002, Georgia Power entered into a fifteen-year PPA beginning in
June&nbsp;2005 with Southern Power to purchase 1,040 megawatts of capacity from
Southern Power&#146;s Plant McIntosh. See Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150;
&#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in
Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power
under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein for information regarding the FERC approval process
for this PPA.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in
the ordinary course of business. In addition, Georgia Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public
health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of
various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The
ultimate outcome of such litigation against Georgia Power cannot be predicted
at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if
any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect
on Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future earnings potential.


<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Georgia Power
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s results
of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements
could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in
the financial statements. See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150;
&#147;Accounting Policies &#151; Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Georgia Power in
the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Georgia Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation and Contingent
Obligations.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004,
Georgia Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation No.
46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related assets and
liabilities. The adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on Georgia
Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption, Georgia Power
deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts

</DIV>

definition of primary beneficiary established by Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See
Note (E)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information related to the adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The major change in Georgia Power&#146;s
financial condition during the first three months of 2004 was the addition of
approximately $159&nbsp;million to utility plant. The funds for these additions and
other capital requirements were derived primarily from operating activities.
See Georgia Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash Flows herein for further
details.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Financial Condition and
Liquidity &#151; Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Georgia Power
in the Form 10-K for a description of Georgia Power&#146;s capital requirements for
its construction program, lease obligations, purchase commitments and trust
funding requirements. Approximately $252&nbsp;million will be required by March&nbsp;31,
2005 for redemptions and maturities of long-term debt.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other
purposes from sources similar to those used in the past, including funds from
operations and new security issuances. The amount, type and timing of
additional security issuances &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon maintenance of
adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions and other
factors. See Item&nbsp;1 &#151; Business &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in the Form 10-K for
additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets
because of the continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet
cash needs, which can fluctuate significantly due to the seasonality of the
business. To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Georgia Power had
at March&nbsp;31, 2004 approximately $7.0&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and
$725&nbsp;million of unused credit arrangements with banks. These credit
arrangements expire in June&nbsp;2004 and contain provisions allowing two-year term
loans executable at the expiration. Georgia Power expects to renew its credit
facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. The credit arrangements provide
liquidity support to Georgia Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate
pollution control bonds and commercial paper. Georgia Power may also meet
short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue
and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and
for the benefit of Georgia Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At
March&nbsp;31, 2004, Georgia Power had outstanding $192&nbsp;million in notes payable.
Management believes that the need for working capital can be adequately met by
utilizing lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">48
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power does not have any credit agreements that would require material
changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating
downgrade. There are contracts that could require collateral &#151; but not
accelerated payment &#151; in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales, fixed-price physical gas purchases, and agreements
covering interest rate swaps. At March&nbsp;31, 2004, the maximum potential
collateral requirements were approximately $227&nbsp;million.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Georgia Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest
rate changes have not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003
reporting period. In addition, Georgia Power is not aware of any facts or
circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Georgia Power has limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Georgia Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase and
sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser
extent, similar contracts for gas purchases. Georgia Power has also
implemented a retail fuel hedging program at the instruction of the Georgia
PSC. The fair value of derivative energy contracts at March&nbsp;31, 2004 was as
follows:

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
`
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and
Analysis &#151; &#147;Financial Condition and Liquidity  &#151; Market Price Risk&#148; of Georgia
Power in the Form 10-K and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Georgia
Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (G)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $100&nbsp;million of
Series&nbsp;S 4.00% Senior Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2011 and $100&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;T
5.75% Senior Public Income Notes due January&nbsp;15, 2044. The proceeds from these
sales were used in March&nbsp;2004 to redeem all of its outstanding Series&nbsp;H 6.70%
Senior Insured Quarterly Notes due March&nbsp;1, 2011 and Series&nbsp;D 6 5/8% Senior
Notes due March&nbsp;31, 2039.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further in January&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power Capital Trust VII, a statutory
trust, sold $200&nbsp;million of its 5 7/8% Trust Preferred Securities, which are
guaranteed by Georgia Power. The net proceeds from this issuance were used to
redeem the 6.85% Trust Preferred Securities of Georgia Power Capital Trust IV. In connection with this transaction, Georgia Power issued $206
million of its junior subordinated debentures to Georgia Power Capital Trust
VII.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2004, Georgia Power issued $150&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;U Floating
Rate Senior Notes due February&nbsp;17, 2009. The proceeds of this sale were used
for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to
retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost
capital if market conditions permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">50
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
CONDENSED STATEMENTS OF CASH FLOWS (UNAUDITED)


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="79%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2004 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the first
quarter 2004 was $16.8&nbsp;million compared to $14.0&nbsp;million for the corresponding
period in 2003. First quarter 2004 net income increased by $2.8&nbsp;million, or
21.0%, primarily due to higher operating revenues when compared to the same
period in 2003.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<DIV align="center">

</DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Excluding the recovery of fuel expense and certain other
expenses that do not affect net income, retail sales increased by $4.1&nbsp;million,
or 4.3%, for the first quarter 2004 when compared to the corresponding period
in 2003. Energy sales to residential, commercial and industrial customers were
higher by 5.2%, 3.6%, and 2.9%, respectively, in the first quarter 2004 as
compared to the same period in 2003. The increase in retail sales revenue
during the first quarter 2004 is primarily due to a 2.5% increase in customer
growth and favorable weather conditions when compared to the same period in
2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#150; affiliates and Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Revenues
from sales for resale to affiliates and purchases of energy by affiliates will
vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources
at each company within the Southern Company system. These transactions do not
have a significant impact on earnings since this energy is generally sold at
marginal cost and energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues
through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism. The increase in sales for
resale to affiliates is due to available generation being sold to affiliate
companies. The decrease in purchased power from affiliates is the result of a
decrease in the demand for purchased power due to increased self-generation.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>In the first quarter 2004, fuel expense was higher than the
same period in 2003 due primarily to a 23.3% increase in generation to meet
additional demand for energy as well as a 4.8% increase in coal prices and a
1.3% increase in natural gas prices. Since energy expenses are generally
offset by energy revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism,
these expenses do not have a material impact on net income.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">57
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other operation expense</I>. The increase in other operations expense during
the first quarter 2004 is due to a $1.0&nbsp;million increase in marketing
expenses and a $1.3&nbsp;million increase in employee benefit expenses when compared
to the same period in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Distributions on mandatorily redeemable preferred securities. </I>The
decrease in distributions on mandatorily redeemable preferred securities is
due to the redemption of $40&nbsp;million of 7.625% trust preferred
securities during the first quarter 2003 and the redemption of $45&nbsp;million of
7.000% trust preferred securities during the fourth quarter 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors, including Gulf Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price
elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic growth in the service area. For
additional information relating to these issues, see Item&nbsp;1 &#151; Business &#150; The
SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; and Item&nbsp;7 &#150; Management&#146;s Discussion and
Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Gulf Power in the Form 10-K.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental
regulations could affect earnings if such costs are not fully recovered through
Gulf Power&#146;s Environmental Cost Recovery Clause. See Management&#146;s Discussion
and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;7
of the Form 10-K and Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under
&#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004,
civil penalties under the Clean Air Act were increased prospectively to a
maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation. To the extent alleged violations
under the New Source Review litigation are deemed to be continuing, this
increased civil penalty amount could apply to such violations found to continue
after that date. On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S. Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s
petition to review the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s
similar New Source Review action against the TVA.
With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for review, the Court of Appeals&#146;
decision is now final. An adverse outcome of this matter could require
substantial capital expenditures that cannot be determined at this time and
could possibly require payment of substantial penalties. This could affect
future results of operations, cash flows, and possibly financial condition if
such costs are not recovered through regulated rates.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, on April&nbsp;15, 2004, the EPA announced proposed amendments to
its Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology
(BART)&nbsp;guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend
on the development and implementation of the final rules and implementation by
the states, and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">58
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential &#150;
FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued an order that abandoned the SMA test
and adopted a new interim analysis for measuring generation market power. The
FERC also initiated a new rulemaking proceeding that, among other things, will
adopt a final methodology for assessing generation market power. See Note (B)
to the Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; herein for
additional information. Southern Company is filing a request for
rehearing of the FERC&#146;s order. The final outcome of this matter cannot be determined
at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential &#151; FERC Matters&#148; of Gulf Power in the Form 10-K for information on the
FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and notice of proposed rulemaking regarding open
access transmission service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the
ordinary course of business. In addition, Gulf Power&#146;s business activities are
subject to extensive governmental regulation related to public health and the
environment. Litigation over environmental issues and claims of various types,
including property damage, personal injury and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout the United
States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged
exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such litigation against Gulf Power cannot be predicted at this time;
however, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising
from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Gulf
Power&#146;s financial statements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future
earnings potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant
accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Gulf Power in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these policies, certain
estimates are made that may have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements
could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in
the financial statements. See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis &#151;
&#147;Accounting Policies &#151; Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Gulf Power in
the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Gulf Power&#146;s critical
accounting policies and estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation and Contingent
Obligations.

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Gulf Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation No.
46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the primary
beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related assets and
liabilities. The adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact on Gulf
Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption, Gulf Power
deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to issue preferred
securities since Gulf Power does not meet the definition of primary beneficiary
established by Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (E)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information related to the adoption of
Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Gulf Power&#146;s financial condition during the first three months
of 2004 included the addition of approximately $33.1&nbsp;million to utility plant.
The funds for these additions and other capital requirements were derived
primarily from operating activities. See Gulf Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of
Cash Flows herein for further details.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Reference is made to Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Financial
Condition and Liquidity &#151; Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of
Gulf Power in the Form 10-K for a description of Gulf Power&#146;s capital
requirements for its construction program, lease obligations, purchase
commitments and trust funding requirements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described herein, Gulf Power plans to
obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those used in the past. These sources include cash flows from
operating activities, issuances of unsecured debt and pollution control bonds
issued for Gulf Power&#146;s benefit by public authorities. The amount, type and
timing of any future financings &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon market
conditions and regulatory approval. See Item&nbsp;1 &#151; Business &#151; &#147;Financing
Programs&#148; in the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Gulf Power has various
internal and external sources of liquidity. At March&nbsp;31, 2004, Gulf Power had
approximately $2.3&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $56&nbsp;million of
unused committed lines of credit with banks that expire in 2004. Gulf Power
expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. In addition,
Gulf Power has substantial cash flow from operating activities. The credit
arrangements provide liquidity support to Gulf Power&#146;s obligations with respect
to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper. Gulf Power may
also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized
to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the
request and for the benefit of Gulf Power and other Southern Company
subsidiaries. At March&nbsp;31, 2004, Gulf Power had $18&nbsp;million of commercial
paper outstanding. Management believes that the need for working capital can
be adequately met by utilizing lines of credit without maintaining large cash
balances.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">60
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power does not have any credit agreements that would require material
changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating
downgrade.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Gulf Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not
changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting period. In
addition, Gulf Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances that would
significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Gulf Power has limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Gulf Power enters into fixed price contracts for purchase of coal
supplies, the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale
electricity market and, to a lesser extent, similar contracts for gas
purchases. Gulf Power has received approval from the Florida PSC to recover
prudently incurred costs related to its fuel hedging program through the fuel
cost recovery mechanism. The fair value of derivative energy contracts at
March&nbsp;31, 2004 was as follows:

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In April&nbsp;2004, Gulf Power issued $35&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;J 5.875% Senior Notes
due April&nbsp;1, 2044. The proceeds from this issue were used for general corporate
purposes, including Gulf Power&#146;s continuous construction program.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power plans to evaluate, and to the extent possible, retire
higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if
market conditions permit.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">62
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
CONDENSED BALANCE SHEETS (UNAUDITED)


<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2004 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the first
quarter 2004 was $17.3&nbsp;million compared to $21.4&nbsp;million for the corresponding
period of 2003. Earnings in the first quarter 2004 decreased by $4.1&nbsp;million,
or 19%, primarily due to lower wholesale revenues as a result of the
termination of a contract with a subsidiary of Dynegy, Inc. in October&nbsp;2003.
See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Contract
Termination&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Retail sales. </I>Retail sales revenue for the first quarter 2004 increased
when compared to the same period in 2003 primarily as a result of a $13.6
million increase in fuel revenues, which generally do not have an effect on
income. Retail sales revenues, excluding fuel revenues, for the first quarter
2004 to residential, commercial and industrial customers increased 2.7%, 2.5%
and 2.3%, respectively, primarily as a result of economic growth in the service
area when compared to the same period in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; non-affiliates. </I>The decrease in sales for resale to
non-affiliates in the first quarter 2004 as compared to the same period in 2003
is primarily due to the termination of a contract with a subsidiary of Dynegy,
Inc. in October&nbsp;2003. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi
Power under &#147;Contract Termination&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">69
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates and Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>. Revenues
from sales for resale to affiliates, as well as purchases of energy from
affiliates will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of
generating resources at each company within the Southern Company system. These
transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings since the energy is
generally sold at marginal cost and energy purchases are generally offset by
energy revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost
recovery clauses. The increase in sales for resale to affiliates and the
decrease in purchased power from affiliates is a result of
Mississippi Power&#146;s more
economical generating costs when compared to others.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fuel expense. </I>In the first quarter 2004, fuel expense increased when
compared to the same period in 2003 as a result of a 16.5% increase in
generation and a 57.6% increase in cost of oil and gas. Since energy expenses
are generally offset by energy revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and
wholesale fuel cost recovery clauses, these expenses do not have a significant
impact on earnings.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Maintenance expense. </I>The first quarter 2004 increase in maintenance
expense when compared to the same period in 2003 is a result of increased
generation by the combined cycle units at Plant Daniel. Maintenance expense for
the combined cycle units is based on fired operating hours which were 36.8%
higher in the first quarter 2004 when compared to the same period in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Depreciation and amortization. </I>The first quarter 2004 increase in
depreciation and amortization expense when compared to the same period in 2003
is primarily the result of a true-up in 2003 related to the Environmental
Compliance Overview (ECO)&nbsp;Plan. See Note 3 to Mississippi Power&#146;s financial
statements under &#147;Environmental Compliance Overview Plan&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for additional information.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Interest expense. </I>The decreased interest expense for the first quarter
2004 as compared to the same period in 2003 is a result of lower interest rates
on securities outstanding and a reduction in accrued interest expense related
to prior years&#146; income tax adjustments. See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion
and Analysis &#150; Financial Condition and Liquidity &#150; &#147;Financing Activities&#148; of
Mississippi Power in the Form 10-K and Financial Condition and Liquidity &#150;
&#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein for further information on efforts to reduce
interest rates.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Income taxes. </I>The decrease in income taxes of $2.5&nbsp;million, or 18.9%, is
a result of the $6.7&nbsp;million reduction in pretax net income when compared to
the same period in 2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Future Earnings Potential</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous
factors including Mississippi Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to
recover costs related to growing demand and increasingly stricter environmental
standards. Growth in energy sales is subject to a number of factors, which
include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities,
energy conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price
elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic growth in the service area.
For additional information relating to these issues, see Item&nbsp;1 &#151; Business &#150;
The SOUTHERN System &#151; &#147;Risk Factors&#148; and Item&nbsp;7 &#150; Management&#146;s Discussion and
Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential&#148; of Mississippi Power in the Form 10-K.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">70
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Environmental Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s 2004 ECO Plan filing was approved, as filed, by the
Mississippi PSC on March&nbsp;15, 2004 and resulted in a slight decrease in rates
effective April&nbsp;2004. Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other
environmental regulations could affect earnings if such costs cannot continue
to be recovered. See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future
Earnings Potential &#151; Environmental Matters&#148; and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K. As of March&nbsp;15, 2004, civil penalties under the Clean Air Act
were increased prospectively to a maximum of $32,500 per day, per violation.
To the extent alleged violations under the New Source Review litigation are
deemed to be continuing, this increased civil penalty amount could apply to
such violations found to continue after that date. On May&nbsp;3, 2004, the U.S.
Supreme Court denied the EPA&#146;s petition to review the Eleventh Circuit Court of
Appeals&#146; decision in the EPA&#146;s similar New Source Review action against the
TVA. With the denial of the EPA&#146;s petition for
review, the Court of Appeals&#146; decision is now final. An adverse outcome of
this matter could require substantial capital expenditures and could possibly
require substantial penalties. This could affect future results of operations,
cash flows, and possibly financial condition if such costs are not recovered
through regulated rates.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, on April&nbsp;15, 2004, the EPA announced proposed amendments to
its Regional Haze rules with respect to Best Available Retrofit Technology
(BART)&nbsp;guidelines and requirements. The impact of these regulations will depend
on the development and implementation of the final rules and implementation by
the states, and therefore cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>FERC Matters</I>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Item&nbsp;7 &#151;
Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#150; &#147;Future Earnings Potential
&#150; FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K. On April&nbsp;14, 2004, the FERC issued an order that abandoned the SMA test
and adopted a new interim analysis for measuring generation market power. The
FERC also initiated a new rulemaking proceeding that, among other things, will
adopt a final methodology for assessing generation market power. See Note (B)
to the Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;FERC Matters&#148; herein for
additional information. Southern Company is filing a request for
rehearing of the FERC&#146;s order. The
final outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Future Earnings
Potential &#151; FERC Matters&#148; of Mississippi Power in the Form 10-K for information
on the FERC&#146;s order related to RTOs and the notice of proposed rulemaking
regarding open access transmission service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>Other Matters</I>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Note 3 to Mississippi
Power&#146;s financial statements under &#147;Retail Regulatory
Filing&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for information on Mississippi Power&#146;s request to include 266
megawatts of Plant Daniel Units 3 and 4 generating capacity in jurisdictional
cost of service. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be determined.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising
in the ordinary course of business. In addition, Mississippi Power&#146;s business
activities are subject to extensive governmental regulation related to


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">71
</DIV>

MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury and citizen
enforcement of environmental requirements, has increased generally throughout
the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by
alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The
ultimate outcome of such litigation against Mississippi Power cannot be
predicted at this time; however, management does not anticipate that the
liabilities, if any, arising from any such current proceedings would have a
material adverse effect on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion
of various contingencies and other matters which may affect future
earnings potential.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant
accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on
Mississippi Power&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different
assumptions and measurements could produce estimates that are significantly
different from those recorded in the financial statements. See
Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151;
&#147;Accounting Policies &#151; Application of Critical
Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion
of Mississippi Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to
Electric Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, Plant Daniel Capacity and
Plant Daniel Operating Lease. Also see Note (I)&nbsp;to the condensed financial
statements herein for additional information related to Mississippi Power&#146;s
request to include the additional Plant Daniel capacity in jurisdictional cost
of service.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On March&nbsp;31, 2004, Mississippi Power prospectively adopted FASB Interpretation
No.&nbsp;46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; which requires the
primary beneficiary of a variable interest entity to consolidate the related
assets and liabilities. The adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R had no impact
on Mississippi Power&#146;s net income. However, as a result of the adoption,
Mississippi Power deconsolidated certain wholly-owned trusts established to
issue preferred securities since Mississippi Power does not meet the definition
of primary beneficiary established by Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R. See Note (E)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information related to
the adoption of Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financial Condition and Liquidity</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Overview</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Major changes in Mississippi Power&#146;s financial condition during the first three
months of 2004 included the addition of approximately $15.6&nbsp;million to utility
plant financed primarily from operating activities, a reduction in current
liabilities of $102.5&nbsp;million and a $40.1&nbsp;million increase in long-term debt as
a result of re-financing activities. See Mississippi Power&#146;s Condensed
Statements of Cash Flows and &#147;Financing Activities&#148; herein for further details.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">72
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; Financial Condition and
Liquidity &#151; &#147;Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Mississippi
Power in the Form 10-K for a description of Mississippi Power&#146;s capital
requirements for its construction program, lease obligations, purchase
commitments and trust funding requirements.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the financing activities described herein, Mississippi Power
plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from
sources similar to those used in the past. The amount, type and timing of any
financings &#151; if needed &#151; will depend upon maintenance of adequate earnings,
regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions and other factors. See Item
1 &#151; Business &#151; &#147;Financing Programs&#148; in the Form 10-K for additional
information.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, Mississippi Power had at
March&nbsp;31, 2004, approximately $21.3&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and
$100&nbsp;million of unused committed credit arrangements with banks that expire in
2004. Approximately $37.5&nbsp;million of these credit arrangements contain
provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at the expiration date.
Mississippi Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to
expiration. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Mississippi
Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and
commercial paper. Mississippi Power may also meet short-term cash needs
through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial
paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of
Mississippi Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At March&nbsp;31, 2004,
Mississippi Power had $34.9&nbsp;million in outstanding notes payable. Management
believes that the need for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing
lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet
Financing Arrangements</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">See Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis &#151; &#147;Financial Condition and
Liquidity &#151; Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements&#148; and Note 7 to the
financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for information related to Mississippi Power&#146;s lease of a
combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power does not have any credit agreements that would require
material changes in payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit
rating downgrade.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes
have not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2003 reporting
period. In addition, Mississippi Power is not aware of any facts or
circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">73
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulation, Mississippi Power has limited exposure
to market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity. To mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity
prices, Mississippi Power enters into fixed price contracts for the purchase
and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market. Mississippi
Power has also implemented retail fuel hedging programs at the instruction of
its PSC and wholesale fuel hedging programs under agreements with wholesale
customers. The fair values of derivative, fuel and energy contracts at March
31, 2004 were as follows:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="55%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="82%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="6%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see
Item&nbsp;7 &#151; Management&#146;s Discussion and
Analysis &#151; &#147;Financial Condition and Liquidity &#151; Market Price Risk&#148; of
Mississippi Power in the Form 10-K and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements under &#147; Financial Instruments&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K and Note (G)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In March&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued $40&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;F Floating Rate
Senior Notes due March&nbsp;9, 2009. The proceeds from this sale, along with other
monies of Mississippi Power were used to repay at maturity $80&nbsp;million
aggregate principal amount of Mississippi Power&#146;s Series&nbsp;D Floating Rate Senior
Notes due March&nbsp;12, 2004.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">74
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April&nbsp;2004, Mississippi Power issued 1,200,000 Depositary Shares ($30
million aggregate stated capital) each representing one-fourth of a share of
5.25% Series&nbsp;Preferred Stock cumulative, par value $100 per share. The
proceeds from this sale were primarily used to redeem various issues of higher
cost preferred stock and the remainder was used for general corporate purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi Power plans to continue, to the extent possible, a program to
retire higher-cost securities and replace these securities with lower-cost
capital.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">75
</DIV>

    <TD align="right"><HR size="4" noshade>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right"><HR size="4" noshade>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The accompanying notes as they relate to Savannah Electric are an integral part of these condensed financial statements.



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">81

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SAVANNAH ELECTRIC AND POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
RESULTS OF OPERATIONS AND FINANCIAL CONDITION



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FIRST QUARTER 2004 vs. FIRST QUARTER 2003



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Earnings</B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Savannah Electric&#146;s net income for the first quarter 2004 was $3.1&nbsp;million
compared to $3.5&nbsp;million for the corresponding period of 2003. Earnings
decreased by $0.4&nbsp;million, or 10.3%, in the first quarter 2004, primarily due
to higher operating expenses, partially offset by higher operating revenues.



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the
following:

<DIV align="center">
